sentences.zh: 昔周監於二代，三聖制法，立爵五等，封國八百，同姓五十有餘。

translations.literal: Formerly Zhou observed the two dynasties, the three sages established laws, set up five ranks of nobility, enfeoffed eight hundred states, with over fifty of the same surname.
translations.idiomatic: In ancient times, the Zhou dynasty drew lessons from the Xia and Shang. The three sage kings established a system of five noble ranks, enfeoffing over eight hundred states, with more than fifty ruled by members of the royal family.

sentences.zh: 周公、康叔建於魯、衛，各數百里；

translations.literal: The Duke of Zhou and Kangshu were established in Lu and Wei, each several hundred li;
translations.idiomatic: The Duke of Zhou was enfeoffed in Lu and Duke Kang in Wei, each domain spanning several hundred square li;

sentences.zh: 太公於齊，亦五侯九伯之地。

translations.literal: Taigong in Qi, also the land of five marquises and nine earls.
translations.idiomatic: The Grand Duke was enfeoffed in Qi, a territory as large as that of five marquises and nine earls.

sentences.zh: 詩載其制曰：「介人惟藩，大師惟垣。

translations.literal: The Poems record their system saying: "The elite man is the screen, the great master is the wall.
translations.idiomatic: The Book of Odes describes their system: "The noble men serve as protective screens, the great ministers as sturdy walls.

sentences.zh: 大邦惟屏，大宗惟翰。

translations.literal: The great state is the screen, the great lineage is the pinion.
translations.idiomatic: Great states serve as shields, great clans as supporting wings.

sentences.zh: 懷德惟寧，宗子惟城。

translations.literal: Cherishing virtue brings peace, the lineage sons are the rampart.
translations.idiomatic: Those who cherish virtue find peace, the royal clansmen form the city defenses.

sentences.zh: 母俾城壞，毋獨斯畏。」

translations.literal: Do not let the rampart be destroyed, do not be alone in this fear."
translations.idiomatic: Do not allow the defenses to crumble, do not face this danger alone."

sentences.zh: 所以親親賢賢，褒表功德，關諸盛衰，深根固本，為不可拔者也。

translations.literal: This was to favor relatives and esteem the worthy, praise and display meritorious virtue, relate it to prosperity and decline, deeply root and firmly establish the foundation, making it something that cannot be uprooted.
translations.idiomatic: This system honored relatives and rewarded the worthy, publicly recognized meritorious deeds, and tied the fate of these noble houses to the dynasty fortunes, creating deep roots and strong foundations that could not be uprooted.

sentences.zh: 故盛則周、邵相其治，致刑錯；

translations.literal: Therefore when prosperous then Zhou and Shao assisted their governance, bringing about the laying aside of punishments;
translations.idiomatic: In times of prosperity, the Zhou and Shao clans assisted in governance, achieving such harmony that punishments were set aside;

sentences.zh: 衰則五伯扶其弱，與共守。

translations.literal: when declining then the five hegemons supported their weakness, and guarded together with them.
translations.idiomatic: in times of decline, the five hegemons supported their weakness and helped defend the realm.

sentences.zh: 自幽、平之後，日以陵夷，至虖阨挢河洛之間，分為二周，有逃責之臺，被竊鈇之言。

translations.literal: From after King You and King Ping, day by day declining, until constrained and bent between the Yellow River and Luo River, divided into two Zhou, having the terrace of escaping responsibility, covered by the words of stolen authority.
translations.idiomatic: After the reigns of Kings You and Ping, the dynasty steadily declined. It was squeezed between the Yellow and Luo Rivers, split into Eastern and Western Zhou, with kings fleeing their duties and suffering the condemnation of usurped authority.

sentences.zh: 然天下謂之共主，彊大弗之敢傾。

translations.literal: Yet the world called it the common lord, the strong and great did not dare overthrow it.
translations.idiomatic: Yet the world still recognized it as the common sovereign, and even the strongest powers dared not overthrow it.

sentences.zh: 歷載八百餘年，數極德盡，既於王赧，降為庶人，用天年終。

translations.literal: Passed through eight hundred and more years, fate exhausted and virtue depleted, arrived at King Nan, descended to commoner status, ended with natural lifespan.
translations.idiomatic: It endured for over eight hundred years, until its fate was exhausted and virtue depleted. By King Nan's time, it had descended to commoner status and ended with a natural death.

sentences.zh: 號位已絕於天下，尚猶枝葉相持，莫得居其虛位，海內無主，三十餘年。

translations.literal: The title and position already cut off from the world, still the branches and leaves supported each other, none could occupy its empty position, within the seas without a master, more than thirty years.
translations.idiomatic: Though the Zhou title and position had ended, the remaining branches of the family still propped each other up. No one could claim the vacant throne, leaving the empire without a ruler for over thirty years.

translations.literal: In ancient times, the Zhou dynasty drew lessons from the Xia and Shang. The three sage kings established a system of five noble ranks, enfeoffing over eight hundred states, with more than fifty ruled by members of the royal family. The Duke of Zhou was enfeoffed in Lu and Duke Kang in Wei, each domain spanning several hundred square li; The Grand Duke was enfeoffed in Qi, a territory as large as that of five marquises and nine earls. The Book of Odes describes their system: "The noble men serve as protective screens, the great ministers as sturdy walls. Great states serve as shields, great clans as supporting wings. Those who cherish virtue find peace, the royal clansmen form the city defenses. Do not allow the defenses to crumble, do not face this danger alone." This system honored relatives and rewarded the worthy, publicly recognized meritorious deeds, and tied the fate of these noble houses to the dynasty fortunes, creating deep roots and strong foundations that could not be uprooted. In times of prosperity, the Zhou and Shao clans assisted in governance, achieving such harmony that punishments were set aside; in times of decline, the five hegemons supported their weakness and helped defend the realm. After the reigns of Kings You and Ping, the dynasty steadily declined. It was squeezed between the Yellow and Luo Rivers, split into Eastern and Western Zhou, with kings fleeing their duties and suffering the condemnation of usurped authority. Yet the world still recognized it as the common sovereign, and even the strongest powers dared not overthrow it. It endured for over eight hundred years, until its fate was exhausted and virtue depleted. By King Nan's time, it had descended to commoner status and ended with a natural death. Though the Zhou title and position had ended, the remaining branches of the family still propped each other up. No one could claim the vacant throne, leaving the empire without a ruler for over thirty years.

sentences.zh: 秦據勢勝之地，騁狙詐之兵，蠶食山東，壹切取勝。

translations.literal: Qin occupied strategically advantageous land, employed cunning and deceitful troops, nibbled away at Shandong, in everything achieved victory.
translations.idiomatic: Qin occupied strategically superior territory and deployed cunning, deceitful armies. They gradually devoured the eastern states, achieving victory in every endeavor.

sentences.zh: 因矜其所習，自任私知，姍笑三代，盪滅古法，竊自號為皇帝，而子弟為��夫，內亡骨肉本根之輔，外亡尺土藩翼之衛。

translations.literal: Thereupon proud of their accustomed ways, relied on private knowledge, ridiculed the three dynasties, destroyed ancient laws, stole the title emperor, and made sons and younger brothers marquises, internally without close relatives as root assistants, externally without an inch of land as border guards.
translations.idiomatic: Proud of their accustomed ways and trusting only their own wisdom, they ridiculed the three ancient dynasties, destroyed traditional laws, and arrogated the title of emperor for themselves. They made their sons and brothers marquises, but had no close relatives as trusted advisors within, and no territorial buffer as external defense.

sentences.zh: 陳、吳奮其白挺，劉、項隨而斃之。

translations.literal: Chen and Wu raised their plain clubs, Liu and Xiang followed and destroyed them.
translations.idiomatic: Chen She and Wu Guang raised their wooden staves in rebellion, and Liu Bang and Xiang Yu followed to destroy the Qin dynasty.

sentences.zh: 故曰，周過其曆，秦不及期，國勢然也。

translations.literal: Therefore it is said, Zhou exceeded its calendar, Qin did not reach the period, the state's power was thus.
translations.idiomatic: Hence the saying: Zhou outlasted its allotted time, Qin fell short of its destiny - such are the fortunes of states.

translations.literal: Qin occupied strategically superior territory and deployed cunning, deceitful armies. They gradually devoured the eastern states, achieving victory in every endeavor. Proud of their accustomed ways and trusting only their own wisdom, they ridiculed the three ancient dynasties, destroyed traditional laws, and arrogated the title of emperor for themselves. They made their sons and brothers marquises, but had no close relatives as trusted advisors within, and no territorial buffer as external defense. Chen She and Wu Guang raised their wooden staves in rebellion, and Liu Bang and Xiang Yu followed to destroy the Qin dynasty. Hence the saying: Zhou outlasted its allotted time, Qin fell short of its destiny - such are the fortunes of states.

sentences.zh: 漢興之初，海內新定，同姓寡少，懲戒亡秦孤立之敗，於是剖裂疆土，立二等之爵。

translations.literal: At the beginning of Han's rise, within the seas newly settled, same surname few and sparse, learning from the Qin's defeat of isolation, thereupon divided the territory, established two ranks of nobility.
translations.idiomatic: At the founding of the Han dynasty, the empire was newly unified but the royal family was small. Learning from Qin's disastrous isolation, they divided the territories and established a two-tier system of nobility.

sentences.zh: 功臣侯者百有餘邑，尊王子弟，大啟九國。

translations.literal: Meritorious ministers enfeoffed as marquises, over a hundred towns; honored the king's sons and younger brothers, greatly opened nine states.
translations.idiomatic: Meritorious ministers were enfeoffed as marquises in over a hundred towns. The emperor's sons and brothers were honored, and nine major kingdoms were established.

sentences.zh: 自鴈門以東，盡遼陽，為燕、代。

translations.literal: From Yanmen eastward, reaching Liaoyang, for Yan and Dai.
translations.idiomatic: From Yanmen eastward to Liaoyang became the kingdoms of Yan and Dai.

sentences.zh: 常山以南，太行左轉，度河、濟，漸于海，為齊、趙。

translations.literal: South of Changshan, Taihang turning left, crossing the Yellow River and Ji River, reaching the sea, for Qi and Zhao.
translations.idiomatic: South of Mount Changshan, where the Taihang Mountains turn westward, crossing the Yellow River and Ji River to the sea, became the kingdoms of Qi and Zhao.

sentences.zh: 穀、泗以往，奄有龜、蒙，為梁、楚。

translations.literal: From Gu and Si westward, encompassing Gui and Meng, for Liang and Chu.
translations.idiomatic: Westward from the Gu and Si Rivers, encompassing Mount Gui and Mount Meng, became the kingdoms of Liang and Chu.

sentences.zh: 東帶江、湖，薄會稽，為荊吳。

translations.literal: East bordering the Jiang and Hu, approaching Kuaiji, for Jing Wu.
translations.idiomatic: To the east bordering the Yangtze and lakes, extending to Kuaiji, became the kingdoms of Jing and Wu.

sentences.zh: 北界淮瀕，略廬、衡，為淮南。

translations.literal: Northern boundary the Huai River banks, encompassing Lu and Heng, for Huainan.
translations.idiomatic: Bordered to the north by the Huai River, encompassing Mount Lu and Mount Heng, became the kingdom of Huainan.

sentences.zh: 波漢之陽，亙九嶷，為長沙。

translations.literal: Rippling south of the Han River, extending to Jiuyi, for Changsha.
translations.idiomatic: South of the Han River, extending to the Jiuyi Mountains, became the kingdom of Changsha.

sentences.zh: 諸侯北境，周市三垂，外接胡越。

translations.literal: The northern borders of the feudal lords, encircling the markets of the three extremities, externally connecting with the Hu and Yue.
translations.idiomatic: The northern frontiers of these kingdoms encircled the border markets, connecting externally with the Xiongnu and Yue tribes.

sentences.zh: 天子自有三河、東郡、潁川、南陽，自江陵以西至巴蜀，北自雲中至隴西，與京師內史凡十五郡，公主、列侯頗邑其中。

translations.literal: The Son of Heaven himself possessed Sanhe, Dongjun, Yingchuan, Nanyang, from Jiangling westward to Bashu, north from Yunzhong to Longxi, together with the Capital Interior Commandery making fifteen commanderies total, princesses and marquises having many towns among them.
translations.idiomatic: The emperor directly controlled the commanderies of Sanhe, Dongjun, Yingchuan, and Nanyang. From Jiangling westward to Bashu, and northward from Yunzhong to Longxi, plus the Capital Interior Commandery, made fifteen commanderies in total. Princesses and marquises also held many towns within these areas.

sentences.zh: 而藩國大者夸州兼郡，連城數十，宮室百官同制京師，可謂撟枉過其正矣。

translations.literal: But the great feudal states boasted of encompassing provinces and commanderies, connecting dozens of cities, palaces and officials following the same system as the capital, can be called bending the crooked exceeding the straight.
translations.idiomatic: Yet the largest feudal kingdoms boasted territories spanning entire provinces and commanderies, controlling dozens of connected cities. Their palaces and officials followed the same system as the imperial capital - one might say they bent the rules beyond what was proper.

sentences.zh: 雖然，高祖創業，日不暇給，孝惠享國又淺，高后女主攝位，而海內晏如，亡狂狡之憂，卒折諸呂之難，成太宗之業者，亦賴之於諸侯也。

translations.literal: Although this was so, Gaozu established the enterprise, days not sufficient, Emperor Hui enjoyed the state shallowly, Empress Gao female ruler held position, yet within the seas peaceful as usual, without mad cunning worries, finally broke the Lü clan difficulty, completed Emperor Taizong's enterprise, also relied on the feudal lords.
translations.idiomatic: Nevertheless, when Gaozu founded the dynasty, he was overwhelmed with daily affairs. Emperor Hui's reign was brief, and Empress Gao ruled as regent. Yet the empire remained peaceful, free from rebellious plots. The Lü clan's usurpation was ultimately thwarted, and Emperor Wen's reign was secured - all thanks to the support of the feudal lords.

translations.literal: At the founding of the Han dynasty, the empire was newly unified but the royal family was small. Learning from Qin's disastrous isolation, they divided the territories and established a two-tier system of nobility. Meritorious ministers were enfeoffed as marquises in over a hundred towns. The emperor's sons and brothers were honored, and nine major kingdoms were established. From Yanmen eastward to Liaoyang became the kingdoms of Yan and Dai. South of Mount Changshan, where the Taihang Mountains turn westward, crossing the Yellow River and Ji River to the sea, became the kingdoms of Qi and Zhao. Westward from the Gu and Si Rivers, encompassing Mount Gui and Mount Meng, became the kingdoms of Liang and Chu. To the east bordering the Yangtze and lakes, extending to Kuaiji, became the kingdoms of Jing and Wu. Bordered to the north by the Huai River, encompassing Mount Lu and Mount Heng, became the kingdom of Huainan. South of the Han River, extending to the Jiuyi Mountains, became the kingdom of Changsha. The northern frontiers of these kingdoms encircled the border markets, connecting externally with the Xiongnu and Yue tribes. The emperor directly controlled the commanderies of Sanhe, Dongjun, Yingchuan, and Nanyang. From Jiangling westward to Bashu, and northward from Yunzhong to Longxi, plus the Capital Interior Commandery, made fifteen commanderies in total. Princesses and marquises also held many towns within these areas. Yet the largest feudal kingdoms boasted territories spanning entire provinces and commanderies, controlling dozens of connected cities. Their palaces and officials followed the same system as the imperial capital - one might say they bent the rules beyond what was proper. Nevertheless, when Gaozu founded the dynasty, he was overwhelmed with daily affairs. Emperor Hui's reign was brief, and Empress Gao ruled as regent. Yet the empire remained peaceful, free from rebellious plots. The Lü clan's usurpation was ultimately thwarted, and Emperor Wen's reign was secured - all thanks to the support of the feudal lords.

sentences.zh: 然諸侯原本以大，末流濫以致溢，小者淫荒越法，大者睽孤橫逆，以害身喪國。

translations.literal: Yet the feudal lords originally established as great, the later generations overflowed with abuse leading to excess, small ones licentious and lawless exceeding the law, great ones estranged and isolated perverse and rebellious, harming themselves and losing their states.
translations.idiomatic: However, the feudal lords were originally established as powerful rulers, but later generations abused their power excessively. The smaller ones became licentious and lawless, while the greater ones grew estranged, isolated, and rebellious, ultimately destroying themselves and losing their kingdoms.

sentences.zh: 故文帝采賈生之議分齊、趙，景帝用晁錯之計削吳、楚。

translations.literal: Therefore Emperor Wen adopted Jia Sheng's proposal to divide Qi and Zhao, Emperor Jing used Chao Cuo's plan to reduce Wu and Chu.
translations.idiomatic: Therefore Emperor Wen adopted Jia Yi's proposal to divide Qi and Zhao, while Emperor Jing implemented Chao Cuo's plan to reduce the power of Wu and Chu.

sentences.zh: 武帝施主父之冊，下推恩之令，使諸侯王得分戶邑以封子弟，不行黜陟，而藩國自析。

translations.literal: Emperor Wu implemented Zhu Fu's memorial, issued the command of extending kindness, causing the feudal lords to divide households and towns to enfeoff their sons and younger brothers, not carrying out promotion and demotion, and the feudal states divided themselves.
translations.idiomatic: Emperor Wu implemented Zhu Fu's proposal and issued the Edict of Extended Kindness, allowing feudal lords to divide their territories to enfeoff their sons and brothers. Without formal demotions, the kingdoms gradually fragmented on their own.

sentences.zh: 自此以來，齊分為七趙分為六，梁分為五，淮南分為三。

translations.literal: From this time onward, Qi was divided into seven, Zhao into six, Liang into five, Huainan into three.
translations.idiomatic: From this point on, Qi was split into seven parts, Zhao into six, Liang into five, and Huainan into three.

sentences.zh: 皇子始立者，大國不過十餘城。

translations.literal: Imperial sons newly established, great kingdoms not exceeding ten and several cities.
translations.idiomatic: When imperial sons were newly enfeoffed as kings, even the largest kingdoms contained no more than a dozen or so cities.

sentences.zh: 長城、燕、代雖有舊名，皆亡南北邊矣。

translations.literal: Changcheng, Yan, Dai although having old names, all lacked north and south borders.
translations.idiomatic: Though Changcheng, Yan, and Dai retained their ancient names, they no longer had northern or southern frontiers to defend.

sentences.zh: 景遭七國之難，抑損諸侯，減黜其官。

translations.literal: Jing encountered the difficulty of the seven states, suppressed and diminished the feudal lords, reduced and demoted their officials.
translations.idiomatic: Emperor Jing faced the Rebellion of the Seven States, suppressed the feudal lords, and reduced the ranks of their officials.

sentences.zh: 武有衡山、淮南之謀，作左官之律，設附益之法，諸侯惟得衣食稅租，不與政事。

translations.literal: Wu had the plots of Hengshan and Huainan, made the law of left officials, established the method of attaching benefits, feudal lords only obtained clothing food tax rent, not participating in government affairs.
translations.idiomatic: Emperor Wu dealt with the rebellions of Hengshan and Huainan by creating the law of "left officials" and establishing rules for royal succession. Feudal lords could only collect taxes and rents for their living expenses, with no role in governing.

translations.literal: However, the feudal lords were originally established as powerful rulers, but later generations abused their power excessively. The smaller ones became licentious and lawless, while the greater ones grew estranged, isolated, and rebellious, ultimately destroying themselves and losing their kingdoms. Therefore Emperor Wen adopted Jia Yi's proposal to divide Qi and Zhao, while Emperor Jing implemented Chao Cuo's plan to reduce the power of Wu and Chu. Emperor Wu implemented Zhu Fu's proposal and issued the Edict of Extended Kindness, allowing feudal lords to divide their territories to enfeoff their sons and brothers. Without formal demotions, the kingdoms gradually fragmented on their own. From this point on, Qi was split into seven parts, Zhao into six, Liang into five, and Huainan into three. When imperial sons were newly enfeoffed as kings, even the largest kingdoms contained no more than a dozen or so cities. Though Changcheng, Yan, and Dai retained their ancient names, they no longer had northern or southern frontiers to defend. Emperor Jing faced the Rebellion of the Seven States, suppressed the feudal lords, and reduced the ranks of their officials. Emperor Wu dealt with the rebellions of Hengshan and Huainan by creating the law of "left officials" and establishing rules for royal succession. Feudal lords could only collect taxes and rents for their living expenses, with no role in governing.

sentences.zh: 至於哀、平之際，皆繼體苗裔，親屬疏遠，生於帷牆之中，不為士民所尊，勢與富室亡異。

translations.literal: Until the time of Ai and Ping, all were continuing body descendants, relatives distant, born within the curtain walls, not honored by scholars and commoners, power not different from wealthy families.
translations.idiomatic: By the reigns of Emperors Ai and Ping, all the kings were distant descendants of the original imperial family, born and raised in isolated palaces. They commanded no respect from officials or commoners, their power no different from that of wealthy commoners.

sentences.zh: 而本朝短世，國統三絕，是故王莽知漢中外殫微，本末俱弱，亡所忌憚，生其姦心；

translations.literal: And the present dynasty short generations, state succession three times broken, therefore Wang Mang knew Han inside and outside exhausted and weak, root and branch both weak, nothing to be feared, gave birth to his treacherous heart;
translations.idiomatic: Moreover, the dynasty had brief reigns with three successions broken. Therefore Wang Mang knew that the Han dynasty was exhausted and weak both internally and externally, root and branch feeble. Having nothing to fear, he conceived his treacherous ambitions.

sentences.zh: 因母后之權，假伊周之稱，顓作威福廟堂之上，不降階序而運天下。

translations.literal: Relying on the empress dowager's authority, borrowing the titles of Yi and Zhou, monopolizing power and fortune in the ancestral hall above, not descending the steps and sequence but operating the world.
translations.idiomatic: Relying on the empress dowager's power and claiming the mantle of the ancient sages Yi Yin and Duke Zhou, he monopolized authority in the imperial court, controlling the empire's fate without leaving the palace halls.

sentences.zh: 詐謀既成，遂據南面之尊，分遣五威之吏，馳傳天下，班行符命。

translations.literal: Deceitful plans already completed, then occupied the southern facing honor, divided and sent the five majesty officials, galloped imperial couriers throughout the world, distributed and carried out the talismanic commands.
translations.idiomatic: His deceitful schemes accomplished, he seized the imperial throne facing south. He dispatched his Five Majesty officials and sent imperial couriers galloping throughout the empire to proclaim his divine mandates.

sentences.zh: 漢諸侯王厥角绷首，奉上璽韍，惟恐在後，或乃稱美頌德，以求容媚，豈不哀哉！

translations.literal: The Han feudal lords knelt with twisted heads, presented the imperial seals and ribbons, fearing only to be behind, some even praised beauty and recited virtue, to seek favor and flattery, is it not lamentable!
translations.idiomatic: The Han dynasty's feudal kings knelt with bowed heads, presenting the imperial seals and cords. They feared only falling behind others. Some even composed flattering praises of virtue to curry favor. How lamentable this is!

sentences.zh: 是以究其終始彊弱之變，明監戒焉。

translations.literal: Therefore thoroughly investigate the changes of beginning and end, strength and weakness, clearly take as a warning.
translations.idiomatic: Therefore, by thoroughly examining the cycles of rise and fall, strength and weakness, we gain clear lessons for the future.

translations.literal: By the reigns of Emperors Ai and Ping, all the kings were distant descendants of the original imperial family, born and raised in isolated palaces. They commanded no respect from officials or commoners, their power no different from that of wealthy commoners. Moreover, the dynasty had brief reigns with three successions broken. Therefore Wang Mang knew that the Han dynasty was exhausted and weak both internally and externally, root and branch feeble. Having nothing to fear, he conceived his treacherous ambitions. Relying on the empress dowager's power and claiming the mantle of the ancient sages Yi Yin and Duke Zhou, he monopolized authority in the imperial court, controlling the empire's fate without leaving the palace halls. His deceitful schemes accomplished, he seized the imperial throne facing south. He dispatched his Five Majesty officials and sent imperial couriers galloping throughout the empire to proclaim his divine mandates. The Han dynasty's feudal kings knelt with bowed heads, presenting the imperial seals and cords. They feared only falling behind others. Some even composed flattering praises of virtue to curry favor. How lamentable this is! Therefore, by thoroughly examining the cycles of rise and fall, strength and weakness, we gain clear lessons for the future.

translations.idiomatic: The Yan king restored a broken line, Gaomi succeeded his father; total of six persons.

sentences.zh: 右孝元二人。

translations.idiomatic: Above: Two kings from Emperor Yuan's era.

sentences.zh: 廣陵繼絕，凡三人。

translations.literal: Guangling continued the broken line, altogether three persons.
translations.idiomatic: Guangling restored a broken line; total of three persons.

sentences.zh: 孝成時河間、廣德、定陶三國，孝哀時廣平一國，孝平時東平、中山、廣德、廣世、廣宗五國，皆繼絕。

translations.literal: During Xiaocheng time Hejian, Guangde, Dingtao three states; during Xiao'ai time Guangping one state; during Xiaoping time Dongping, Zhongshan, Guangde, Guangshi, Guangzong five states, all continued broken lines.
translations.idiomatic: During Emperor Cheng's reign: Hejian, Guangde, and Dingtao (three kingdoms restored broken lines). During Emperor Ai's reign: Guangping (one kingdom). During Emperor Ping's reign: Dongping, Zhongshan, Guangde, Guangshi, and Guangzong (five kingdoms restored broken lines).

translations.literal: Above: Two kings from Emperor Yuan's era. Guangling restored a broken line; total of three persons. During Emperor Cheng's reign: Hejian, Guangde, and Dingtao (three kingdoms restored broken lines). During Emperor Ai's reign: Guangping (one kingdom). During Emperor Ping's reign: Dongping, Zhongshan, Guangde, Guangshi, and Guangzong (five kingdoms restored broken lines).
